sentences: Danielle Bregoli (born March 26, 2003), known professionally as Bhad Bhabie (, "bad baby"), is an American rapper, songwriter, and internet personality.
section: N/A

sentences: She first became known from an appearance on Dr. Phil in September 2016, in which she uttered the phrase, "Cash me outside, how bout dat?", which became a viral video meme and catchphrase.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2017, Bregoli became the youngest female rapper ever to appear on the Billboard Hot 100 chart with her debut single "These Heaux".
section: N/A

sentences: She subsequently signed a record deal with Atlantic Records and has since expanded into a reality show, a makeup brand, tours, and a music career.
section: N/A

sentences: Bregoli released her first mixtape, 15, in September 2018.
section: N/A

sentences: Its lead single, "Hi Bich", became her second single to appear on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
section: N/A

sentences: Bregoli was born and raised in Boynton Beach, Florida.
section: == Life and career == | === 2003–2015: Early life and background ===

sentences: Her parents, Ira Peskowitz and Barbara Ann Bregoli, dated for a year before Barbara became pregnant, later separating when she was an infant.
section: == Life and career == | === 2003–2015: Early life and background ===

sentences: Her father is Jewish and her mother is of Italian descent.
section: == Life and career == | === 2003–2015: Early life and background ===

sentences: Bregoli was raised in a Catholic household primarily by her mother, and is estranged from her father, a deputy who works for the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office.

== Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: On September 14, 2016, Bregoli and her mother Barbara Ann were interviewed on Dr. Phil for a segment titled "I Want to Give Up My Car-Stealing, Knife-Wielding, Twerking 13-Year-Old Daughter Who Tried to Frame Me for a Crime".
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: They appeared on the show to discuss Bregoli's behavior, which included stealing a crew member's car while the episode was being filmed.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: When Bregoli became irritated at the audience's laughter, she responded to them by saying "Catch me outside, how about that?", challenging them to a fight outside the studio.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: Her deliberately forced accent made the phrase sound like "Cash me ousside, how bout dah", which became a meme, and Bregoli became known as the "'Cash Me Outside' Girl".
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: On February 10, 2017, Bregoli reappeared on the show, but without a studio audience due to the response at her previous appearance.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: Her first appearance on the show, and the catchphrase it spawned, would inspire a single based on the clip, ("Cash Me Outside") which was recorded by DJ Suede The Remix God, and entered the Billboard Hot 100, Streaming Songs, and Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs charts in its March 4, 2017 issue.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: The song, in turn, led to a series of dance videos that were uploaded onto YouTube.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: Bregoli and her mother sued three companies for "infringing her intellectual property rights" by using her signature catchphrase without consent.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: She also threatened to sue Walmart for using her catchphrase on T-shirts.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: She was nominated for the 2017 MTV Movie & TV Awards in the "Trending" category based on the catchphrase.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: Following her appearance on Dr. Phil, Bregoli spent time at the Turn-About Ranch, a facility for "troubled teens" in Utah.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: She was later arrested and pleaded guilty to charges of grand theft, marijuana possession, and filing a false police report, for which she was sentenced to five years' probation in July 2017, but it ended earlier in March 2018, after she hired a new lawyer.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: In March 2021, Bregoli uploaded a video to her YouTube channel in which she says she experienced and witnessed abuse at the Turn-About Ranch.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: She accused staffers of forcing her to sit still for three days straight without being allowed to sleep, using physical restraint on other teenagers, and ignoring reports of bullying.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: She also criticized Dr. Phil for sending teenagers on his show to the facility.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===

sentences: He responded via an April 2021 interview with NewsNation that he is unaware of the ranch's actions and does not get feedback from them, to which Bregoli reacted by saying in a second video that the ranch sends progress reports directly to the show.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2017: Dr. Phil appearance, rehab, and legal issues ===
